The Scorecard Fallacy: How Promotion Decisions Are Really Made Many of us, especially those who excelled in structured environments like school, carry a particular model of the world into our careers. We tend to believe that advancement, like getting good grades, is the result of a fair, well-calculated, numerical system. Do task A, get 10 points. Do task B, get 20. Rack up enough points, outperform others on the scorecard, and a promotion is the logical outcome.
